channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DATAMONGO-127] @Document(collection="SOME_COLLECTION_NAME") doesn't take effect
item.description:
Hi all,I check out spring-data-document source from git,version e4fdabb.I found that the @Document annotation support a collection value,does this mean the collection where the POJO shold save to?

So I've makd some tests(ie @Document(collection="test")),but the POJO still save to a collection which just used the POJO's class name.

Does there a bug or I just use the @Document annotation in a wrong way?
item.environment: windows xp sp3,sun-jdk-1.6.0_21,spring 3.0.5,spring-data-document from git version e4fdabb

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
1. there is not 1.0 GA Verision out yet
2. How did you configure the mapper?
3. Do you use the MappingMongoConverter or the SimpleMongoConverter?

1.I just check the source from the master chunck,so I didn't no which version it is ,apologize for this.
2.It is very simple,just like
@Document(collection="...")
public class foo{
@Id private String id;
//other properties
//getter and setters
}
3.I don't use a MappingMongoConverter nor SimpleMongoConverter,I just configure data document like this:
<mongo:mongo host="xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx" port="27017">
<mongo:mongo>

<bean id="mongoTemplate" class="org.springframework.data.document.mongodb.MongoTemplate">
<constructor-arg ref="mongo"/>
<constructor-arg><value>DEFAULT_DB_NAME</value></constructor-arg>
</bean>

Try this:

<bean id="mongoTemplate" class="org.springframework.data.document.mongodb.MongoTemplate">
<constructor-arg name="mongo" ref="mongo" />
<constructor-arg name="databaseName" value="$

{mongo.database}

" />
<constructor-arg name="defaultCollectionName" value="$

{mongo.collection}

" />
<constructor-arg ref="converter" />
</bean>

<mongo:mapping-converter id="converter"/>

Thanks for your help Matthias.
I had configured it just like you do,but the property 'defaultCollectionName' has been removed in version 68f8bd62d182f7f40fdf11f13904c7d7d7cfdcd8 ,and the @Document annotation contains a new 'collection' property,it looks like to tell MongoTemopate which collection it should saved to,and I read the source I think I am right.
But when I build the newest source code by maven ,and put it in my project,the @Document annotation dose'nt take effect,as I reported.

see:
https://fisheye.springsource.org/rdiff/datadoc/spring-data-mongodb/src/main/java/org/springframework/data/document/mongodb/MongoTemplate.java?r1=68f8bd62d182f7f40fdf11f13904c7d7d7cfdcd8&r2=e4fdabba1dc3abcff686f825aa46051825b50d0a&u&N

The MappingMongoConverter is responsible for reading those annotations and doing the more high-level "mapping" type functionality. We have several tests that deal with custom collections, so I'm pretty sure it will work as expected if you configure the mapping converter by using the 3-arg constructor MongoTemplate(Mongo mongo, String databaseName, MongoConverter mongoConverter).

Just like Matthias has with the exception you'd drop the "defaultCollectionName" arg. The important one is to give the template a mapping-converter instance it can use to actually read and respect those annotations.

There is code in the org.springframework.data.document.mongodb.mapping.MappingTests class that deals with custom collections if you need examples. There are POJOs that use this as well in the same package.

Sorry for the confusion. We are deprecating SimpleMongoConverter for M3 and by default MongoTemplate will use MappingMongoConverter so explicit configuration will not be necessary to make use of @Document or any other annotations. Thanks for the help Matthias!

Tested with the latest snapshot and it seems to work with a default configuration for the MongoTemplate. Closing this for the upcoming M3 release. Feel free to open new issue if you are still having problems.
